title: Julia-themed Quarto
text:
Julia-themed Quarto.



The quarto-julia repo is a simple Quarto extension that makes a number of Julia-themed Custom Formats for Quarto available.
On this website you can find a number of examples that demonstrate how the extension can be used and what kind of output it can produce.
As you may have guessed from the design, this very website uses the quarto-julia extension.

title: Julia-themed Revealjs
text: Tired of PowerPoint? How about using a Revealjs for your next presentation instead. You can find an example slide deck here.

title: Revealjs Presentation
text:
Details
The quarto-julia theme is based on the default theme and adds various custom formatting options.

title: Revealjs Presentation
text:
Font The theme imports three font faces: The JuliaMono font, which by default is used for all headers and code. The Roboto font, which is used as the default font for everything else (just like on julialang.org/). The Bangla MN by Muthu Nedumaran of Murasu Systems, which is closely related to the official Julia logo font. The Bangla MN can be used to style individual elements like so:

Some fancy text.

Some fancy text. Bangla MN Copyright This Bangla MN font is copyrighted by MN, so make sure you are allowed to use it.

title: Revealjs Presentation
text:
Code
Inline code looks like this print("hello üåç").
Code chunks looks like this:
# lifted from: https://github.com/mossr/BeautifulAlgorithms.jl/blob/master/src/neural_network.jl

using LinearAlgebra

ReLU(z) = max(z, 0)

function neural_network(x, ùêï, ùê∞, œÜ, g=ReLU)
    ùê° = map(ùêØ‚±º -> g(ùêØ‚±º ‚ãÖ œÜ(x)), ùêï)
    ùê∞ ‚ãÖ ùê°
end

title: Revealjs Presentation
text:
Math
Let \(t\in\{0,1\}\) denote the target label, \(M\) the model (classifier) and \({x}^{\prime} \in \mathbb{R}^D\) the vector of counterfactual features. In order to generate recourse the GenericGenerator optimizes the following objective function through steepest descent
\[
x\prime = \arg \min_{x\prime}  \ell(M(x\prime),t) + \lambda h(x\prime)
\]
where \(\ell\) denotes some loss function targeting the deviation between the target label and the predicted label and \(h(\cdot)\) is a complexity penalty generally addressing the realism or cost of the proposed counterfactual.

title: Quarto and Documenter.jl
text: Since Documenter.jl takes Markdown documents as input, you can use Quarto with Documenter.jl for package documentation. To make this as painless as possible, the documenterjl-commonmark format specifies a few relevant output option.

title: Julia-themed Articles
text: This page you‚Äôre on now is a citeable article.

title: Julia-themed Articles
text:
Introduction
This Quarto notebook generates Julia-themed output.

title: Julia-themed Articles
text:
Details
The quarto-julia theme is based on the default theme and adds various custom formatting options.

Let \(t\in\{0,1\}\) denote the target label, \(M\) the model (classifier) and \({x}^{\prime} \in \mathbb{R}^D\) the vector of counterfactual features. In order to generate recourse the GenericGenerator optimizes the following objective function through steepest descent
\[
x\prime = \arg \min_{x\prime}  \ell(M(x\prime),t) + \lambda h(x\prime)
\]
where \(\ell\) denotes some loss function targeting the deviation between the target label and the predicted label and \(h(\cdot)\) is a complexity penalty generally addressing the realism or cost of the proposed counterfactual.
